articles.title: An outbreak at a choir practice hints at how coronavirus spreads - Salon
articles.description: "The act of singing itself might have contributed to SARS-CoV-2 transmission," the CDC says of a choir practice outbreak
articles.content: On Tuesday the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) cited a two-and-a-half hour choir practice in Washington state as an example of a "superspreader event" and argued that it "underscores the importance of physical distancing, including avoiding gathering in lar… [+3880 chars]

articles.author: Tanner Stening | tstening@masslive.com
articles.title: Massachusetts health officials announce 174 new coronavirus deaths, 1,165 new cases - MassLive.com
articles.description: The state's Department of Public Health released the latest coronavirus statistics on Wednesday.
articles.content:
Health officials on Wednesday announced that another 174 Massachusetts residents have died of coronavirus, bringing the total number of fatalities to 5,315.
Officials also confirmed another 1,165 new cases of the virus, bringing the statewide total to 80,497… [+2206 chars]

articles.author: KATU Staff
articles.title: Oregon COVID-19 death toll hits 134, OHA reports 3,338 cases statewide - KATU
articles.description: PORTLAND, Ore. – Four more people have died in Oregon from COVID-19, health officials said Wednesday, as the state’s total number of identified coronavirus cases climbs to 3,338 patients. So far, 134 people have died in Oregon related to the coron…

articles.title: 108-year-old man may be the oldest survivor of COVID-19 - WLKY Louisville
articles.description: “I didn’t even know I had it. … I guess if I knew I had it I might have been scared.”
articles.content:
At 108, Phil Corio is certainly one of the oldest people in New Mexico and the U.S.
But now the Los Ranchos resident has a new claim to fame: he just might be the oldest person in the world to survive COVID-19.
Phils son, 58-year-old Ron Corio, said he and … [+3521 chars]

articles.author: Isobel Asher Hamilton
articles.title: UK accidentally leaves contact-tracing app plans on open Google Drive - Business Insider - Business Insider
articles.description: Future versions of the app might ask for more data, track geolocation, and allow people to set a "COVID-19 status."
articles.content:
The UK government accidentally revealed some of its future plans for its COVID-19 contact-tracing app by leaving them on a publicly accessible Google Drive.
The drive was spotted by Wired UK, and contained documents including one entitled "Product Direction:… [+2562 chars]
